Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced, Accelerated Computational System for Lattice QCD
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is the theory of strong interactions, the fundamental force in Nature that binds quarks and gluons into subatomic particles (hadrons), such as protons and neutrons. The study of QCD properties is one of the central scientific challenges in nuclear physics. Nuclear physics scientists use computational methods and large-scale simulations to further the detailed understanding of hadronic structure. These simulations make use of state-of-the-art computational resources and researchers continue to improve their high-performance computing (HPC) methods to take advantage of the latest breakthrough in computer technology. This project will allow the acquisition of a parallel computer cluster incorporating the next-generation Intel multi-core processors (Knights Landing) and a high-performance communication network. The Knights Landing architecture has the potential to revolutionize scientific computing, by providing large computing resources at low cost and using significantly less power than conventional computer clusters. This computer cluster will be housed in a state-of-the-art computing center in the new Integrated Science Center at the College of William & Mary and will form the centerpiece of high-performance computing on the W&M campus.

The primary scientific driver for the system is to use lattice QCD methods to build a solid foundation for nuclear physics based on the Standard Model of elementary particle physics. With increased computational power and recent algorithmic developments, the research carried out with this system will advance the Lattice QCD program. This system will be used as a test bed for the development of new algorithms for lattice QCD calculations. These algorithms will be designed in collaboration with computer scientists specifically for the modern multi-core architectures that are currently the trent in high-performance computing. Furthermore, this computer cluster will serve as the center of interdisciplinary research between computer scientists and physicists and will catalyze the integration of research and education through the training of students and postdoctoral researchers in the groups of the senior investigators and in the wider academic community at William and Mary.

This project advances the objectives of the National Strategic Computing Initiative (NSCI), an effort aimed at sustaining and enhancing the U.S. scientific, technological, and economic leadership position in High-Performance Computing (HPC) research, development, and deployment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project built a parallel computer cluster using the next generation Intel multi-core processors (Knights Landing) and a high-performance (OmniPath) communication network.  The Knights Landing architecture has the potential to revolutionize scientific computing, by providing large computing resources at low cost and using significantly less power than conventional computer clusters.  The cluster has now 100 compute nodes each one having 192Gb of memory one OmiPath network card, an 800Gb SSD drive, and a single Intel Xeon Phi 7230 (KNL) processor.  Futhermore, the head node that runs the queuing system is a Dell  PowerEdge  R630 server with dual socket Intel Xeon E5-2630 processor, 128Gb of memory and  1Tb of local storage. Finally, a 120Tb fileserver is added to the system.  The cluster is housed in a state-of-the-art computing center in the new Integrated Science Center at the College of William and Mary and forms the centerpiece of high-performance computing on our campus. Over the period of the award, the computer hardware was selected and purchased. The  HPC group at William and Mary built the cluster, installed and configured the software and produced documentation for the the usage of the cluster. The machine became operational in friendly user mode in February 2017 and after one month it was ready for general use. Since then the machine has been working flawlessly and already one publication and one seminar were the enabled by this cluster. 

 

The parallel computer cluster serves a group of computational scientists from a range of scientific domains, their postdoctoral research associates, and many undergraduate and graduate students. Researchers in nuclear, particle and condensed matter physics, materials science, computer science and other areas are currently the system to advance our understanding of Nature at multiple scales down to the most fundamental. A primary scientific driver for the system is to use a computational method known as lattice QCD to build a solid foundation for nuclear physics based on the Standard Model of elementary particle physics. The existence of this machine on campus has helped enlarge the Lattice  QCD group at William and Mary, which  now has there faculty members. 

 

An important goal of this project  is to integrate research and education through the training of students and postdoctoral researchers in the groups of the senior investigators and in the wider community.  Currently there are two postdoctoral fellows and six graduate students are  using the system. This community of users is going to grow as time goes by and the new users get familiar with the new architecture and adapt accordingly their  algorithms. 

The system is also supporting William and Mary’s interdisciplinary Computational Science Cluster that aims to broaden the role of computation in research and education, and will be utilized as an instructional resource in undergraduate and graduate courses.

The web page with details about the status of the machine can be found at:

http://www.wm.edu/offices/it/services/hpc/hw/nodes/meltemi/index.php
